node.contents: Thank You kingdomcreation for answer, CDATA I have to avoid such stuffs

astNode.text: Thank You kingdomcreation for answer, CDATA I have to avoid such stuffs

node.contents: Am I getting it right that the problem is in `<` being translated to `<` and ruininig the markup? If so, then why don't you just escape the whole string once again before feeding it to the parser?

astNode.text: Am I getting it right that the problem is in `<` being translated to `<` and ruininig the markup? If so, then why don't you just escape the whole string once again before feeding it to the parser?

node.contents: What encoding are you using on the file?

astNode.text: What encoding are you using on the file?

node.contents: You could use CDATA blocks and/or keep writing the xml as "Regular" xml nodes and add the xml declaration when reading your file.

astNode.text: You could use CDATA blocks and/or keep writing the xml as "Regular" xml nodes and add the xml declaration when reading your file.

node.contents: You could also specify the <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> declaration.

astNode.text: You could also specify the <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> declaration.

node.contents: The Problem was solved I decoded the format and parsed

astNode.text: The Problem was solved I decoded the format and parsed
